Z_{1, \rho}:=\int\left\{Z_{Y}(y, x)\left[F_{W \mid X}(w \mid x)-.5\right]+Z_{W}(w, x)\left[F_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)\right.\right. & \left.\left.--.5]\right\} \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(y, w, z) \\
& +G_{Z}\left(\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right]\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right]\right) \\
Z_{2, \rho}:=2 \int Z_{W}(w, x)\left[F_{W \mid X}(w \mid x)-.5\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(y, w, z) & +G_{Z}\left(\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right]^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
Z_{3, \rho}:=2 \int Z_{Y}(y, x)\left[F_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)-.5\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(y, w, z)+G_{Z}\left(\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right]^{2}\right)
$$

(2) $\widehat{\rho}_{C}$ has the same limit distribution as $\tilde{\rho}_{C}$ because

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\rho}_{C}-\tilde{\rho}_{C}\right) \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} 0
$$

The variance of the limit processes $Z_{1, \rho}$ and $Z_{\rho}$ have complicated expressions that might be difficult to estimate analytically. To avoid this difficulty, we propose the use of bootstrap to make inference. We show that the exchangeable bootstrap draws of Algorithm 2 have the same asymptotic distribution as the CRRR estimators under the following assumption on the weights:

Assumption 6.2 (Exchangeable Bootstrap). For each $n,\left(\omega_{n 1}, \ldots, \omega_{n n}\right)$ is an exchangeable, ${ }^{17}$ nonnegative random vector, which is independent of the data, such that for some $\epsilon>0$

$$
\sup _{n} \mathrm{E}\left[\omega_{n 1}^{2+\epsilon}\right]<\infty, n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\omega_{n i}-\bar{\omega}_{n}\right)^{2} \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} 1, \bar{\omega}_{n} \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} 1
$$

where $\bar{\omega}_{n}=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \omega_{n i}$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{17} \mathrm{~A}$ sequence of random variables $X_{1}, X_{2}, \ldots, X_{n}$ is exchangeable if for any finite permutation $\sigma$ of the indices $1,2, \ldots, n$ the joint distribution of the permuted sequence $X_{\sigma(1)}, X_{\sigma(2)}, \ldots, X_{\sigma(n)}$ is the same as the joint distribution of the original sequence.

In order to state the results about bootstrap validity formally, we follow the notation and definitions in van der Vaart et al. (1996). Let $D_{n}$ denote the data vector and $M_{n}$ be the vector of random variables used to generate bootstrap draws given $D_{n}$. Consider the random element $\mathbb{Z}_{n}^{*}=$ $\mathbb{Z}_{n}\left(D_{n}, M_{n}\right)$ in a normed space $\mathbb{E}$. We say that the bootstrap law of $\mathbb{Z}_{n}^{*}$ consistently estimates the law of some tight random element $\mathbb{Z}$ and write $\mathbb{Z}_{n}^{*} \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}} \mathbb{Z}$ in $\mathbb{E}$ if:

$$
\sup _{h \in \mathrm{BL}_{1}(\mathbb{E})}\left|\mathrm{E}_{M_{n}} h\left(\mathbb{Z}_{n}^{*}\right)-\mathrm{E} h(\mathbb{Z})\right| \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} 0
$$

where $\mathrm{BL}_{1}(\mathbb{E})$ denotes the space of functions with Lipschitz norm at most 1 and $\mathrm{E}_{M_{n}}$ denotes the conditional expectation with respect to $M_{n}$ given the data $D_{n}$; and $\rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}}$ denotes convergence in (outer) probability.

We now provide a bootstrap central limit theorem for the estimators of the CRRR slope. This result follows from a functional central limit theorem for the input processes, which we establish in Lemma B. 4 in Appendix B, and the functional delta method for the bootstrap.

Theorem 6.2 (Exchangeable Bootstrap Consistency). Under the conditions of Lemma 6.1 and Assumption 6.2: in $\mathbb{R}$,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\tilde{\rho}_{C}^{*}-\tilde{\rho}_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}} Z_{\rho}, \quad \sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\rho}_{C}^{*}-\widehat{\rho}_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}} Z_{\rho}, \quad \text { and } \quad \sqrt{n}\left(\tilde{\rho}_{C}^{*}-\widehat{\rho}_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}} Z_{1, \rho}
$$

that is, exchangeable bootstrap consistently estimates the law of the limit processes $Z_{\rho}$ and $Z_{1, \rho}$. In particular,

$$
\widehat{\sigma}_{\rho} \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} \sigma_{\rho} \text { and } \mathrm{P}\left\{\rho_{C} \in A C I_{1-\alpha}\left(\rho_{C}\right)\right\} \rightarrow 1-\alpha \text { as } n \rightarrow \infty
$$

where $\sigma_{\rho}$ is the standard deviation of the limit process $Z_{\rho}$, and $\widehat{\sigma}_{\rho}$ and $A C I_{1-\alpha}\left(\rho_{C}\right)$ are defined in Algorithm 3 .

# 7. CONCLUSION 

This paper introduces the conditional rank-rank regression (CRRR) as an alternative to traditional rank-rank regressions with covariates (RRRX) for measuring within-group mobility and persistence. The CRRR uses conditional ranks of the variables of interest given covariates, in contrast to RRRX which uses marginal ranks net of covariate effects. We show that the CRRR slope preserves an intuitive interpretation as the average conditional rank correlation between the variables, similar to RRR without covariates. In contrast, the slope of RRRX loses the rank correlation interpretation and can take on values outside the interval $[-1,1]$. The CRRR is also suitable for subgroup analysis, where the CRRR slopes maintain a rank correlation interpretation conditional on the groups.

We propose a distribution regression estimator for CRRR where the conditional distributions are modeled flexibly using parametric link functions. The estimator is easy to implement and computationally tractable. We derive asymptotic theory for the estimator based on the functional delta method. The analytic asymptotic variance is cumbersome, so we propose an exchangeable bootstrap procedure for inference. The bootstrap procedure is also used to construct confidence

intervals. We illustrate the usefulness of CRRR in an empirical application to intergenerational income mobility in Switzerland. The application reveals stronger intergenerational persistence between fathers and sons than fathers and daughters, where the within-group persistence accounts for between $52 \%$ and $79 \%$ of the overall persistence. We also find some evidence of heterogeneity across groups defined by father's education and family size. The results are robust to the exclusion of child's covariates and the use of logistic or Gaussian link functions.

In summary, CRRR provides a well-grounded measure of within-group mobility and persistence. It also allows us to decompose the overall persistence captured by RRR into within-group persistence captured by CRRR plus a remainder term interpretable as between-group persistence. The distribution regression estimator, coupled with exchangeable bootstrap inference, provides a practical and flexible way to implement CRRR in empirical applications. We expect CRRR will be a useful addition to the toolkit of methods for studying mobility and persistence.

# Appendix A. Regression-Based Estimators 

Algorithm 4 (Regression-based Estimators). Steps (1)-(3) are the same as in Algorithm 1. In step (4) estimate $\rho_{C}$ as either (a) the slope of the linear regression of $\widehat{U}_{i}$ on $\widehat{V}_{i}$, that is

$$
\widehat{\varrho}_{C}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \widehat{U}_{i}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-\overline{\widehat{V}}\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-\overline{\widehat{V}}\right)^{2}}, \quad \overline{\widehat{V}}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \widehat{V}_{i}
$$

or (b) the slope of the restricted linear regression of $\widehat{U}_{i}$ on $\widehat{V}_{i}$, that is

$$
\widehat{\rho}_{C}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}}
$$

Theorem A. 1 (Limit Distribution of $\hat{\rho}_{C}$ and $\widehat{\rho}_{C}$ ). Under the conditions of Lemma 6.1: (1) in $\mathbb{R}$,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\hat{\rho}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12\left[Z_{1, \rho}-\rho_{C} Z_{2, \rho}\right]
$$

where $Z_{1, \rho}$ and $Z_{2, \rho}$ are zero-mean Gaussian random variables defined in Theorem 6.1. (2) $\widehat{\rho}_{C}$ has the same limit distribution as $\hat{\rho}_{C}$ because

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\rho}_{C}-\hat{\rho}_{C}\right) \rightarrow_{\mathrm{P}} 0
$$

Comment A. 1 (Reverse Regression-Based Estimators). The limit distribution of the reverse regressionbased estimator can be trivially obtained from the regression-based case by relabeling the variables $Y$ and $W$. Thus, let $\hat{r}_{C}$ denote the reverse regression-based restricted estimator, that is

$$
\hat{r}_{C}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}}
$$

By Theorem A.1, switching the roles of $Y$ and $W$,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\hat{r}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12\left[Z_{1, \rho}-\rho_{C} Z_{3, \rho}\right] \text { in } \mathbb{R}
$$

where $Z_{3, \rho}$ is a zero-mean Gaussian random variable defined in Theorem 6.1.
Comment A. 2 (Correlation-based vs. Regression-based Estimators). The correlation-based estimators are asymptotically equivalent to the average of the regression-based and reversed regressionbased restricted estimators. To see this equivalence, we combine $\sqrt{n}\left(\hat{\rho}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12\left[Z_{1, \rho}-\rho_{C} Z_{2, \rho}\right]$ with $\sqrt{n}\left(\hat{r}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12\left[Z_{1, \rho}-\rho_{C} Z_{3, \rho}\right]$ to get

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\left(\hat{\rho}_{C}+\hat{r}_{C}\right) / 2-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12\left[Z_{1, \rho}-\rho_{C}\left(Z_{2, \rho}+Z_{3, \rho}\right) / 2\right] \text { in } \mathbb{R}
$$

The same result applies for the average of the regression-based and reversed regression-based unrestricted estimators.

Comment A. 3 (Relative Efficiency). The relative asymptotic efficiency of the different estimators depends on the variances of the components of the limit processes and the correlations between them. For example, the fully-restricted estimator $\hat{\rho}_{C}$ is relatively more efficient than the regressionbased restricted estimator $\hat{\rho}_{C}$ if

$$
\operatorname{Cor}\left(Z_{1, \rho}, \rho Z_{2, \rho}\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\operatorname{Var}\left(\rho Z_{2, \rho}\right)}{\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1, \rho}\right)}}
$$

and relative to the correlation-based estimator $\hat{\rho}_{C}$ if

$$
\operatorname{Cor}\left(Z_{1, \rho}, \rho\left(Z_{2, \rho}+Z_{3, \rho}\right) / 2\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\operatorname{Var}\left(\rho\left(Z_{2, \rho}+Z_{3, \rho}\right) / 2\right)}{\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{1, \rho}\right)}}
$$

The correlation-based estimator is relatively more efficient than the regression-based restricted estimator if $\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{2, \rho}\right)=\operatorname{Var}\left(Z_{3, \rho}\right)$ and $\operatorname{Cov}\left(Z_{1, \rho}, Z_{2, \rho}\right)=\operatorname{Cov}\left(Z_{1, \rho}, Z_{3, \rho}\right)$.

# Appendix B. Proofs of Section 6 

B.1. Hadamard Differentiability of CRRR Functionals. We start by establishing the Hadamard differentiability of the fully-restricted functional $\phi_{1}$ defined in (6.2) and characterizing the expression of the corresponding derivative. Next, we establish the Hadamard differentiability of the correlation-based and regression-based functionals $\phi$ and $\varphi$ defined in (6.1) and (6.3), respectively, and characterize the corresponding derivatives. We provide a brief proof for the results for $\phi$ and $\varphi$ because they follow by similar arguments as the proof for $\phi_{1}$.

We need some setup and preliminary observations. For $\mathcal{R} \in\{\mathcal{Y}, \mathcal{W}\}$, let $\ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X})$ denote the set of all bounded and measurable mappings $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X} \mapsto \mathbb{R}$. Let $\overline{\mathbb{R}}:=\mathbb{R} \cup\{-\infty, \infty\}$ be the extended real line. We consider $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}$ as a subset of $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+1}$, with relative topology. Let $\rho$ denote a standard metric on $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+1}$. The closure of $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}$ under $\rho$, denoted $\overline{\mathcal{R X}}$, is compact in $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+1}$. Let $U C(\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}, \rho)$ be the set of functions mapping $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}$ to the real line that are uniformly continuous with respect to the metric $\rho$, and can be continuously extended to $\overline{\mathcal{R X}}$, so that $U C(\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}, \rho) \subset \ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X})$. For a class of functions $\mathcal{F}$, let $U C(\mathcal{F}, \lambda)$ be the set of functionals mapping $\mathcal{F}$ to the real line that are uniformly continuous with respect to the (semi) metric $\lambda(f, \bar{f})=\left[\mathrm{P}(f-\bar{f})^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}$.

Lemma B. 1 (Hadamard differentiability of $\phi_{1}$ ). Let $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d_{x}+1}, \mathcal{R} \in\{\mathcal{Y}, \mathcal{W}\}$, and $\mathcal{F}$ be the class of bounded functions, mapping $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+2}$ to $\mathbb{R}$, that contains $F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Y \mid X} F_{W \mid X}$ and the indicators of all the rectangles in $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+2}$, such that $\mathcal{F}$ is totally bounded under $\lambda$. Let $\mathbb{D}_{\phi}$ be the product of the spaces of measurable functions $\Gamma_{Y}: \mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \mapsto[-.5, .5]$ defined by $(y, x) \mapsto \Gamma_{Y}(y, x)$ and $\Gamma_{W}: \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X} \mapsto[-.5, .5]$ defined by $(w, x) \mapsto \Gamma_{W}(w, x)$, and the bounded maps $\Pi: \mathcal{F} \mapsto \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f \mapsto \int f \mathrm{~d} \Pi$, where $\Pi$ is restricted to be a probability measure on $\mathcal{Z}:=\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}$. Consider the map $\phi_{1}: \mathbb{D}_{\phi_{1}} \subset \mathbb{D}=\ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y}) \times \ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}) \times \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{F}) \rightarrow$ $\mathbb{E} \subset \mathbb{R}$, defined by

$$
\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right) \mapsto \phi_{1}\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right):=\int \Gamma_{Y}(y, x) \Gamma_{W}(w, x) \mathrm{d} \Pi(z)
$$

Then the map $\phi_{1}$ is well defined. Moreover, the map $\phi_{1}$ is Hadamard-differentiable at $\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right)=$ $\left(F_{Y \mid X}-.5, F_{W \mid X}-.5, F_{Z}\right)$, tangentially to the subset $\mathbb{D}_{0}=U C(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}, \rho) \times U C(\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}, \rho) \times U C(\mathcal{F}, \lambda)$, with the derivative map $\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right) \mapsto \phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right)$ mapping $\mathbb{D}$ to $\mathbb{E}$ defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right):=\int \gamma_{Y}(y, x)\left[F_{W \mid X}(w \mid x)-1 / 2\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(y, w, x) \\
&+\int \gamma_{W}(w, x)\left[F_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)-1 / 2\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(y, w, x) \\
&+\int\left[F_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)-1 / 2\right]\left[F_{W \mid X}(w \mid x)-1 / 2\right] \mathrm{d} \pi(y, w, x),
\end{aligned}
$$

and the derivative is defined and is continuous on $\mathbb{D}$.
Proof of Lemma B.1. First we show that the map $\phi_{1}$ is well defined. Any probability measure $\Pi$ on $\mathcal{Z}$ is determined by the values $\int f \mathrm{~d} \Pi$ for $f \in \mathcal{F}$, since $\mathcal{F}$ contains all the indicators of the rectangles in $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+2}$. By Caratheodory's extension theorem $\Pi(A)=\Pi 1_{A}$ is well defined on all

Borel subsets $A$ of $\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}+2}$. Since $z \mapsto \Gamma_{Y}(y, x) \Gamma_{W}(y, x)$ is Borel measurable and takes values in $\left[-.5^{2}, .5^{2}\right]$, it follows that $\int \Gamma_{Y}(y, x) \Gamma_{W}(w, x) \mathrm{d} \Pi(z)$ is well defined as a Lebesgue integral, and $\int \Gamma_{Y}(y, x) \Gamma_{W}(w, x) \mathrm{d} \Pi(z) \in \mathbb{R}$.

Next we show the main claim. We establish the Hadamard differentiability of $\phi_{1}$. Consider any sequence $\left(\Gamma_{Y}^{t}, \Gamma_{W}^{t}, \Pi^{t}\right) \in \mathbb{D}_{\phi}$ such that for $\gamma_{Y}^{t}:=\left(\Gamma_{Y}^{t}-F_{Y \mid X}+.5\right) / t, \gamma_{W}^{t}:=\left(\Gamma_{W}^{t}-F_{W \mid X}+.5\right) / t$, and $\pi^{t}(f):=\int f \mathrm{~d}\left(\Pi^{t}-F_{Z}\right) / t$,

$$
\left(\gamma_{Y}^{t}, \gamma_{W}^{t}, \pi^{t}\right) \rightarrow\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right), \text { in } \ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}) \times \ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}) \times \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{F}), \text { where }\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right) \in \mathbb{D}_{0}
$$

We want to show that as $t \searrow 0$

$$
\frac{\phi_{1}\left(\Gamma_{Y}^{t}, \Gamma_{W}^{t}, \Pi^{t}\right)-\phi_{1}\left(F_{Y \mid X}-.5, F_{W \mid X}-.5, F_{Z}\right)}{t}-\phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{t}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right) \rightarrow 0 \text { in } \mathbb{R}
$$

Write the difference above as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int\left(\gamma_{Y}^{t}-\gamma_{Y}\right)\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}+\int\left(\gamma_{W}^{t}-\gamma_{W}\right)\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}+\int\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right]\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right]\left(\mathrm{d} \pi^{t}-\mathrm{d} \pi\right) \\
& +\int \gamma_{Y}\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}+\int \gamma_{W}\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right] t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}+\int\left(\gamma_{Y}^{t}-\gamma_{Y}\right)\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t} \\
& +\int\left(\gamma_{W}^{t}-\gamma_{W}\right)\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right] t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}+\int \gamma_{Y}^{t} \gamma_{W}^{t} t \mathrm{~d} F_{Z}+\int \gamma_{Y}^{t} \gamma_{W}^{t} t^{2} \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

The first two terms of (B.1) are bounded by $\left\|\gamma_{R}^{t}-\gamma_{R}\right\|_{\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}} \int \mathrm{d} F_{Z} \rightarrow 0, R \in\{Y, W\}$. The third term vanishes, since for any $f \in \mathcal{F}, \int f \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t} \rightarrow \int f \mathrm{~d} \pi$ in $\ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{F})$, and $\left[F_{Y \mid X}-.5\right]\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] \in \mathcal{F}$ by assumption. The fourth and fifth terms vanish by the argument provided below. The sixth and seventh term vanish, since $\left|\int\left(\gamma_{R}^{t}-\gamma_{R}\right) t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}\right| \leqslant\left\|\gamma_{R}^{t}-\gamma_{R}\right\|_{\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}} \int\left|t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}\right| \leqslant 2\left\|\gamma_{R}^{t}-\gamma_{R}\right\|_{\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}} \rightarrow 0$ for $R \in\{Y, W\}$, where $\int|\mathrm{d} \mu|$ is the total variation of the signed measure $\mu$. The eighth term is bounded by $C t \int \mathrm{~d} F_{Z} \rightarrow 0$, for some $C>0$. The last term can be bounded as:

$$
2 t\left\|\gamma_{Y}^{t}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}\left\|\gamma_{W}^{t}\right\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}}=2 t\left\{\left\|\gamma_{Y}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}+o(1)\right\}\left\{\left(\gamma_{W}\right\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}}+o(1)\right\} \rightarrow 0
$$

Here we consider the fourth term $\int \gamma_{Y}\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] t \mathrm{~d} \pi^{t}$ and show that it vanishes. The argument for the fifth term is analogous. Since $\gamma_{Y}$ is continuous on the compact semi-metric space $(\overline{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}, \rho)$, there exists a finite partition of $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+1}$ into non-overlapping rectangular regions $\left(R_{i m}: 1 \leqslant i \leqslant m\right)$ (rectangles are allowed not to include their sides to make them non-overlapping) such that $\gamma_{Y}$ varies at most $\epsilon$ on $\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \cap R_{i m}$. Let $p_{m}(y, x):=\left(y_{i m}, x_{i m}\right)$ if $(y, x) \in \mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \cap R_{i m}$, where $\left(y_{i m}, x_{i m}\right)$ is an arbitrarily chosen point within $\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \cap R_{i m}$ for each $i$; also let $\chi_{i m}(z):=1\left\{(y, x) \in R_{i m}\right\}$. Then,

as $t \rightarrow 0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left|\int \gamma_{Y}\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] t d \pi^{t}\right| \leqslant\left|\int\left(\gamma_{Y}-\gamma_{Y} \circ p_{m}\right) t d \pi^{t}\right|+\left|\int\left(\gamma_{Y} \circ p_{m}\right) t d \pi^{t}\right| \\
& \leqslant\left\|\gamma_{Y}-\gamma_{Y} \circ p_{m}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}} \int\left|t d \pi^{t}\right|+\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left|\gamma_{Y}\left(y_{i m}, x_{i m}\right)\right| t\left|\pi^{t}\left(\chi_{i m}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant 2\left\|\gamma_{Y}-\gamma_{Y} \circ p_{m}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}+\operatorname{tm}\left\|\gamma_{Y}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}} \max _{1 \leqslant i \leqslant m}\left|\pi^{t}\left(\chi_{i m}\right)\right| \\
& \leqslant 2 \epsilon+\operatorname{tm}\left\|\gamma_{Y}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}\left\|\pi^{t}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}} \leqslant 2 \epsilon+\operatorname{tm}\left[\left\|\gamma_{Y}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}\|\pi\|_{\mathcal{F}}+o(1)\right] \leqslant 2 \epsilon+O(t) \rightarrow 2 \epsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

since $\left\|F_{W \mid X}-.5\right\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}}<1$ and $\left\{\chi_{i m}: 1 \leqslant i \leqslant m\right\} \subset \mathcal{F}$, so that $\max _{i}\left|\pi^{t}\left(\chi_{i m}\right)\right| \leqslant\left\|\pi^{t}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}} \rightarrow\|\pi\|_{\mathcal{F}}<$ $\infty .{ }^{18}$ The constant $\epsilon$ is arbitrary, so that the right hand side vanishes as $t \rightarrow 0$.

The derivative is well-defined over the entire $\mathbb{D}$ and is in fact continuous with respect to the norm on $\mathbb{D}$ given by $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}} \vee\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}} \vee\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{F}}$. The third component of the derivative map is trivially continuous with respect to $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{F}}$. The first component is continuous with respect to $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}}$ since

$$
\left|\int\left(\gamma_{Y}-\hat{\gamma}_{Y}\right)\left[F_{W \mid X}-.5\right] \mathrm{d} F_{Z}(z)\right| \leqslant\left\|\gamma_{Y}-\hat{\gamma}_{Y}\right\|_{\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}} \int \mathrm{~d} F_{Z}(z)
$$

The second component is continuous with respect to $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}}$ by an analogous argument. Hence the derivative map is continuous.

Lemma B. 2 (Hadamard differentiability of $\phi$ ). Continuity of the derivative with respect to the norm on $\mathbb{D}$ given by $\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{F} \mathcal{X}} \vee\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}} \vee\|\cdot\|_{\mathcal{F}}$ follows by continuity of $\phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}, \phi_{2, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}$ and $\phi_{3, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}$.

Lemma B. 3 (Hadamard differentiability of $\varphi$ ). Let $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d_{x}+1}, \mathcal{R} \in\{\mathcal{Y}, \mathcal{W}\}$, and $\mathcal{F}$ be the class of bounded functions, mapping $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+2}$ to $\mathbb{R}$, that contains $F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}^{2}, F_{Y \mid X} F_{W \mid X}$ and the indicators of all the rectangles in $\overline{\mathbb{R}}^{d_{x}+2}$, such that $\mathcal{F}$ is totally bounded under $\lambda$. Let $\mathbb{D}_{\phi}$ be the product of the spaces of measurable functions $\Gamma_{Y}: \mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \mapsto[-.5, .5]$ defined by $(y, x) \mapsto \Gamma_{Y}(y, x)$ and $\Gamma_{W}: \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X} \mapsto[-.5, .5]$ defined by $(w, x) \mapsto \Gamma_{W}(w, x)$, and the bounded maps $\Pi: \mathcal{F} \mapsto \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f \mapsto \int f \mathrm{~d} \Pi$, where $\Pi$ is restricted to be a probability measure on $\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}$ and $\int \Gamma_{W}(w, x)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \Pi>0$. Consider the map $\varphi: \mathbb{D}_{\phi} \subset \mathbb{D}=$ $\ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y}) \times \ell_{m}^{\infty}(\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}) \times \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{F}) \rightarrow \mathbb{E} \subset \mathbb{R}$, defined by

$$
\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right) \mapsto \varphi\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right):=\frac{\int \Gamma_{Y}(y, x) \Gamma_{W}(w, x) \mathrm{d} \Pi(z)}{\int \Gamma_{W}(w, x)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \Pi(z)}
$$

Then the map $\varphi$ is well defined. Moreover, the map $\varphi$ is Hadamard-differentiable at $\left(\Gamma_{Y}, \Gamma_{W}, \Pi\right)=\left(F_{Y \mid X}-\right.$ $\left.5, F_{W \mid X}-.5, F_{Z}\right)$, tangentially to the subset $\mathbb{D}_{0}=U C(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}, \rho) \times U C(\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}, \rho) \times U C(\mathcal{F}, \lambda)$, with the derivative map $\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right) \mapsto \varphi_{F_{Y \mid X}, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right)$ mapping $\mathbb{D}$ to $\mathbb{E}$ defined by

$$
\varphi_{F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right):=12\left[\phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right)-\rho_{C} \phi_{2, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{W}, \pi\right)\right]
$$

with $\phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{Y}, \gamma_{W}, \pi\right)$ defined as in Lemma B. 1 and $\phi_{2, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(\gamma_{W}, \pi\right)$ defined as in Lemma B.2, where the derivative is defined and is continuous on $\mathbb{D}$.

Proof of Lemma B.3. The result follows by an analogous argument to the proof of Lemma B.2. We omit the proof for the sake of brevity.
B.2. Proof of Lemma 6.1. We start by stating a Lemma with a bootstrap functional central limit theorem for the bootstrap draws of the inputs needed to establish Theorem 6.2. We shall prove this lemma together with Lemma 6.1.

For $R \in\{Y, W\}$, let $(r, x) \mapsto \widehat{Z}_{R}^{*}(r, x):=\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{F}_{R \mid X}^{*}(r \mid x)-\widehat{F}_{R \mid X}(r \mid x)\right)$ and $f \mapsto \widehat{G}_{Z}^{*}(f):=$ $\sqrt{n} \int f \mathrm{~d}\left(\widehat{F}_{Z}^{*}-\widehat{F}_{Z}\right)$, where $\widehat{F}_{R \mid X}^{*}(r \mid x):=\Lambda\left(x^{\prime} \widehat{\beta}_{R}^{*}(r)\right), \widehat{\beta}_{R}^{*}(r)$ is the bootstrap draw of $\widehat{\beta}_{R}(r)$ defined in Algorithm 2 and $\widehat{F}_{Z}^{*}$ is the bootstrap draw of the empirical distribution function of $Z$, be exchangeable bootstrap draws of the empirical processes $(r, x) \mapsto \widehat{Z}_{R}(r, x)$ and $f \mapsto \widehat{G}_{Z}(f)$.

Lemma B. 4 (Bootstrap Limit Processses for Inputs). Under the conditions of Lemma 6.1 and Assumption 6.2, in the metric space $\ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X} \mathcal{F})$,

$$
\left(\widehat{Z}_{Y}^{*}(y, x), \widehat{Z}_{W}^{*}(w, x), \widehat{G}_{Z}^{*}(f)\right) \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}}\left(Z_{Y}(y, x), Z_{W}(w, x), G_{Z}(f)\right)
$$

as stochastic processes indexed by $(y, w, x, f)$, where $\left(Z_{Y}(y, x), Z_{W}(w, x), G_{Z}(f)\right)$ has the same distribution as the limit process in Lemma 6.1.

The proof of Lemmas 6.1 and B. 4 follows similar steps to the proof of Theorem 5.2 in Chernozhukov et al. (2013), suitably modified to extend the process to the tails. The main differences are highlighted in Steps 1, 2, and 3 below.

Step 1. (Results for coefficients and empirical measures). Application of the Hadamard differentiability results for Z-processes in Chernozhukov et al. (2013) gives that, in $\ell^{\infty}(\check{\mathcal{Y}})^{d_{x}} \times \ell^{\infty}(\check{\mathcal{W}})^{d_{x}} \times$ $\ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{F})$,

$$
\left(\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\beta}_{Y}(\cdot)-\beta_{Y}(\cdot)\right), \sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\beta}_{W}(\cdot)-\beta_{W}(\cdot)\right), \widehat{G}_{Z}\right) \rightsquigarrow\left(H_{Y}(\cdot), H_{W}(\cdot), G_{Z}\right)
$$

where $\check{\mathcal{Y}}$ and $\check{\mathcal{W}}$ are any compact strict subsets of $\mathcal{Y}$ and $\mathcal{W}$, respectively, and

$$
r \mapsto H_{R}(r):=-J_{R}(r)^{-1} \mathbb{G}\left(\varphi_{r, \beta}\right), \quad \varphi_{r, \beta}(R, X):=\left[\Lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right)-1\{R \leqslant r\}\right] X
$$

has continuous paths a.s., for $R \in\{Y, W\} .^{19}$
We extend the process $\widehat{\beta}(r)$ to the tails as

$$
\widehat{\beta}_{R}(r)=\widehat{\beta}_{R}(\bar{r})+(r-\bar{r}) \widehat{\alpha}_{R}(\bar{r}) e_{1}, \quad r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \check{\mathcal{R}}
$$

where $e_{1}$ is a unitary $d_{x}$-vector with a one in the first component. Likewise, the estimands are given by

$$
\beta_{R}(r)=\beta_{R}(\bar{r})+(r-\bar{r}) \alpha_{R}(\bar{r}) e_{1} \quad r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \check{\mathcal{R}}
$$

by assumption.
In what follows it is convenient to analyze the estimator for the lower tail, the analysis for estimators for upper tails follows exactly the same steps, switching the signs on the dependent variables, $R \in\{Y, W,-Y,-W\}$. The estimators $\left(\widehat{\beta}_{R}(\bar{r}), \widehat{\alpha}_{R}(\bar{r})\right)$ can be seen as Z-estimators with moment function
$\bar{\varphi}_{\beta, \alpha}(R, X)=\left(\varphi_{\bar{r}, \beta}(R, X)^{\prime}, \varphi_{\alpha}(R, X)\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right)\right)^{\prime}, \varphi_{\alpha}(R, X):=\Lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}(\bar{r})+\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right) \alpha_{R}(\bar{r})\right)-1\left\{R \leqslant r_{0}\right\}$.
Invoking Z-process theory again but this time for the simple case of finite-dimensional space $\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}+1}$, we have that jointly in $R \in\{Y,-Y, W,-W\}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\beta}_{R}(\bar{r})-\beta_{R}(\bar{r}), \widehat{\alpha}_{R}(\bar{r})-\alpha_{R}(\bar{r})\right)^{\prime} \\
& \rightsquigarrow\left[\begin{array}{c}
J_{R}(\bar{r}) \\
\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right) \mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right) X^{\prime}\right] \\
\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right)^{2} \mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)\right] \\
\left.\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right)^{2} \mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)\right] \int_{-1}^{-1} \mathbb{G}\left(\bar{\varphi}_{\beta, \alpha}\right)\right.
\end{array}\right]^{-1} \mathbb{G}\left(\bar{\varphi}_{\beta, \alpha}\right) \\
& =\left[\begin{array}{c}
J_{R}^{-1}(\bar{r}) \mathbb{G}\left(\varphi_{\bar{r}, \beta}\right) \\
\frac{\mathbb{G}\left(\varphi_{\alpha}\right)-\mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right) X\right]^{\prime} J_{R}^{-1}(\bar{r}) \mathbb{G}\left(\varphi_{\bar{r}, \beta}\right)}{\left(r_{0}-\bar{r}\right) \mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)\right]}
\end{array}\right] \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

In fact using Hadamard differentiability results for Z-processes given in Chernozhukov et al. (2013), we conclude that convergence results (B.2) and (B.3) for all $R \in\{Y, W,-Y,-W\}$ hold jointly. ${ }^{20}$

STEP 2. (Main: Results for conditional cdfs). Here we show that,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\widehat{Z}_{Y}, \widehat{Z}_{W}, \widehat{G}_{Z}\right) \rightsquigarrow\left(Z_{Y}, Z_{W}, G_{Z}\right) \text { in } \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X} \mathcal{F}) \\
& \left(\widehat{Z}_{Y}^{*}, \widehat{Z}_{W}^{*}, \widehat{G}_{Z}^{*}\right) \rightsquigarrow_{\mathrm{P}}\left(Z_{Y}, Z_{W}, G_{Z}\right) \text { in } \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{W} \mathcal{X} \mathcal{F})
\end{aligned}
$$

For the body part, $r \in \overline{\mathcal{R}}$, consider the mapping $\nu: \mathbb{D}_{\nu} \subset \ell^{\infty}\left(\overline{\mathcal{R}}^{d_{x}}\right) \rightarrow \ell^{\infty}(\overline{\mathcal{R}} \mathcal{X})$, defined as

$$
b \mapsto \nu(b), \quad \nu(b)(x, y):=\Lambda\left(x^{\prime} b(y)\right)
$$

It is straighforward to deduce that this map is Hadamard differentiable at $b(\cdot)=\beta_{R}(\cdot)$ tangentially to $U C(\mathcal{R}, \rho)^{d_{x}}$ with the derivative map given by:

$$
v \mapsto \nu^{\prime}(v), \quad \nu^{\prime}(v)(r, x)=\lambda\left(x^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right) x^{\prime} v(r)
$$

For the tail part $r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \overline{\mathcal{R}}$, we consider the mapping $\mu: \mathbb{R}^{d_{x}+1} \rightarrow \ell^{\infty}(\mathcal{R} \backslash \overline{\mathcal{R}})$ defined by:

$$
(d, a) \mapsto \mu(d, a), \quad \mu(d, a)(r, x):=\Lambda\left(x^{\prime} d+(r-\bar{r}) a e_{1}\right)
$$

This is also Hadamard differentiable at $(d, a)=\left(\beta_{R}(\bar{r}), \alpha_{R}(\bar{r})\right)$ tangentially to the entire domain with the derivative

$$
(h, u) \mapsto \mu^{\prime}(h, u), \quad \mu^{\prime}(h, u)(r, x)=\lambda\left(x^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right)\left(x^{\prime} h+(r-\bar{r}) u e_{1}\right)
$$

The derivative is a bounded (continuous) linear operator (note that as $r \rightarrow \pm \infty$, the derivative vanishes, with the linear growth factor $r-\bar{r}$ being dominated by the term $\lambda\left(x^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right)$ with exponential tails).

We can now define the "extended map" that combines the body and tail pieces:

$$
(b, d, a) \mapsto \bar{\nu}(b, d, a) ; \quad \bar{\nu}(b, d, a)(r, x):=\nu(b)(r, x) 1(r \in \overline{\mathcal{R}})+\mu(d, a)(r, x) 1(r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \overline{\mathcal{R}})
$$

By combining the two differentiability results above, we can deduce that this map is Hadamard differentiable with the derivative map

$$
(v, h, u) \mapsto \bar{\nu}^{\prime}(v, h, u), \quad \bar{\nu}^{\prime}(v, h, u)(r, x):=\nu^{\prime}(v)(r, x) 1(r \in \overline{\mathcal{R}})+\mu^{\prime}(h, u)(r, x) 1(r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \overline{\mathcal{R}})
$$

Then, the claim follows by the functional delta method, and we find that the limit process is given by

$$
Z_{R}(r, x)=\lambda\left(x^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right) x^{\prime} H_{R}(r), \quad R \in\{Y, W\}
$$

where we now define the extended version of $H_{R}$ as: $H_{R}(r)=\mathbb{G}\left(\psi_{R, r, \beta_{R}}\right)$ where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi_{R, r, \beta_{R}}(R, X)=1\{r \in \overline{\mathcal{R}}\} J_{R}(r)^{-1} \varphi_{r, \beta}(R, X)+1\{r \in \mathcal{R} \backslash \overline{\mathcal{R}}\}\left[J_{R}(\bar{r})^{-1} \varphi_{\bar{r}, \beta}(R, X)\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{r-\bar{r}}{r_{0}-\bar{r}} \frac{\varphi_{\alpha}(R, X)-\mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right) X\right]^{\prime} J_{R}(\bar{r})^{-1} \varphi_{\bar{r}, \beta}(R, X)}{\mathrm{E}\left[\lambda\left(X^{\prime} \beta_{R}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)\right]} e_{1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and letting $\ell_{r, x}(R, X):=\lambda\left(x^{\prime} \beta_{R}(r)\right) x^{\prime} \psi_{r, \beta_{R}}(R, X)$, after some algebra.
STEP 3. (Auxiliary: Donskerness). One key ingredient for the result is to show that $\mathcal{F}$ is a Dudley-Koltchinskii-Pollard (DKP) class, namely it has bounded uniform covering entroy integral and obeys standard measurability condition (Dudley's image-admissible Suslin condition). We omit any discussion of measurability in this paper, but we note that it trivially holds. The proof in Chernozhukov et al. (2013) relies on compactness of the set $\overline{\mathcal{R}} \mathcal{X}$ and does not apply immediately. We extend the result to $\mathcal{R} \mathcal{X}$. For $R \in\{Y, W\}$, note that $\mathcal{F}_{R}=\left\{F_{R \mid X}(r \mid \cdot): r \in \mathcal{R}\right\}$ is a uniformly bounded "parametric" family indexed by $r \in \mathcal{R}$ that obeys $\left|F_{R \mid X}(r \mid \cdot)-F_{R \mid X}\left(r^{\prime} \mid \cdot\right)\right| \leqslant L\left|r-r^{\prime}\right|$, given the assumption that the density function $f_{R \mid X}$ is uniformly bounded by some constant $L$. This was enough to bound the covering numbers for the index set $\overline{\mathcal{R}}$, but is not enough to bound the covering number over the unbounded set $\mathcal{R}$.

Under our modelling hypotheses, there exists a small enough constant $C>0$ such that

$$
F_{R \mid X}(r \mid \cdot) \leqslant \exp (r C) ; \quad r<0 ; \quad 1-F_{R \mid X}(r \mid \cdot) \leqslant \exp (-r C) ; \quad r>0
$$

Let $R_{j}=-M(\epsilon)-\epsilon /(2 L)+j(\epsilon / L)$, with $j=0, \ldots, J$, where $J=\lceil 2 M(\epsilon) L / \epsilon\rceil+1, M(\epsilon)=\log (1 / \epsilon) / C$ and $\lceil\cdot\rceil$ is the ceiling function. Let $R_{-1}=-\infty$ and $R_{J+1}=+\infty$. The sets $B_{j}=\left\{F_{R \mid X}(r \mid X): R_{j} \leqslant\right.$ $r \leqslant R_{j+1}\}$ for $j \in\{-1, \ldots, J\}$ have the $L^{2}$ diameter of at most $\epsilon$ independently of the distribution of $F_{X}$ :

- Indeed by the previous paragraph, if $j \in\{0, \ldots, J-1\}$, then the diameter of the set $B_{j}$ is at most $L(\epsilon / L)=\epsilon$.
- For $j=-1$ or $J$, then any pair of conditional cdfs in the same ball obey:

$$
\left|F_{R \mid X}(r \mid \cdot)-F_{R \mid X}\left(r^{\prime} \mid \cdot\right)\right| \leqslant \exp (-M(\epsilon) C)=\exp (-[\log (1 / \epsilon) / C] C) \leqslant \epsilon
$$

The number of sets is at most $2 \log (1 / \epsilon) L /(C \epsilon)+5$. It follows that the uniform covering entropy of the function set $\mathcal{F}_{R}=\left\{F_{R \mid X}(r \mid X): r \in \mathcal{R}\right\}$ is bounded by $\left(1+(1 / \epsilon)^{2}\right)$ up to a constant that does not depend on the distribution of $X$.

Further if we take $\mathcal{F}$ as generated by union of products of $\mathcal{F}_{R}$ over different labels $R$, and the union of rectangles, the resulting set is still a DKP class, by standard uniform covering entropy calculus.
B.3. Proof of Theorem 6.1. Part (1) follows by the functional delta method (see, e.g., Lemma B. 1 of Chernozhukov et al. (2013)). Indeed, in the notation of Lemma B.2,

$$
\hat{\rho}_{C}=\phi\left(\widehat{F}_{Y \mid X}, \widehat{F}_{W \mid X}, \widehat{F}_{Z}\right)=\frac{\int\left[\widehat{F}_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)-.5\right]\left[\widehat{F}_{W \mid X}(W \mid x)-.5\right] \mathrm{d} \widehat{F}_{Z}(y, w, x)}{\sqrt{\int\left[\widehat{F}_{W \mid X}(W \mid x)-.5\right]^{2} \mathrm{~d} \widehat{F}_{Z}(y, w, x) \int\left[\widehat{F}_{Y \mid X}(Y \mid x)-.5\right]^{2} \mathrm{~d} \widehat{F}_{Z}(y, w, x)}}
$$

and $\rho_{C}=\phi\left(F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}\right)$. By Lemmas B. 2 and 6.1, together with the functional delta method,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\hat{\rho}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow \phi_{F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(Z_{Y}, Z_{W}, G_{Z}\right) \text { in } \mathbb{R}
$$

Similarly, in the notation of Lemma B.1,

$$
\bar{\rho}_{C}=12 \phi_{1}\left(\widehat{F}_{Y \mid X}, \widehat{F}_{W \mid X}, \widehat{F}_{Z}\right)=12 \int\left[\widehat{F}_{Y \mid X}(y \mid x)-.5\right]\left[\widehat{F}_{W \mid X}(W \mid x)-.5\right] \mathrm{d} \widehat{F}_{Z}(y, w, x)
$$

and $\rho_{C}=12 \phi_{1}\left(F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}\right)$. By Lemmas B. 1 and 6.1, together with the functional delta method,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\bar{\rho}_{C}-\rho_{C}\right) \rightsquigarrow 12 \phi_{1, F_{Y \mid X}, F_{W \mid X}, F_{Z}}^{\prime}\left(Z_{Y}, Z_{W}, G_{Z}\right) \text { in } \mathbb{R}
$$

To show part (2), write

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-\overline{\widehat{V}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}-(\overline{\widehat{V}}-.5)^{2}, \quad \overline{\widehat{V}}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \widehat{V}_{i} \\
& \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-\overline{\widehat{U}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}-(\overline{\widehat{U}}-.5)^{2}, \quad \overline{\widehat{U}}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \widehat{U}_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \widehat{U}_{i}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-\overline{\widehat{V}}\right)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)-(\overline{\widehat{U}}-.5)(\overline{\widehat{V}}-.5)
$$

To analyze the second components of the previous expressions, note that

$$
|\overline{\widehat{V}}-.5| \leqslant \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\widehat{V}_{i}-V_{i}\right|+\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(V_{i}-.5\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right), \quad V_{i}=F_{W \mid X}\left(W_{i} \mid X_{i}\right)
$$

by the central limit theorem applied to the second term and

$$
\max _{i \in\{1, \ldots, n\}}\left|\widehat{V}_{i}-V_{i}\right|=\max _{i \in\{1, \ldots, n\}}\left|\widehat{F}_{W \mid X}\left(W_{i} \mid X_{i}\right)-F_{W \mid X}\left(W_{i} \mid X_{i}\right)\right| \leqslant\left\|\widehat{F}_{W \mid X}-F_{W \mid X}\right\|_{\mathcal{W} \mathcal{X}}=O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

where the last equality follows by Lemma 6.1. A similar argument gives $|\overline{\widehat{U}}-.5|=O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, and

$$
\max _{i \in\{1, \ldots, n\}}\left|\widehat{U}_{i}-U_{i}\right|=O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right), \quad U_{i}=F_{Y \mid X}\left(Y_{i} \mid X_{i}\right)
$$

Combining the previous results with the continuous mapping theorem, and using a mean value expansion, we conclude that

$$
\widehat{\rho}_{C}=\frac{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)+O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1}\right)}{\sqrt{\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}+O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1}\right)\right]\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\widehat{U}_{i}-.5\right)^{2}+O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1}\right)\right]}}=\bar{\rho}_{C}+O_{\mathrm{P}}\left(n^{-1}\right)
$$

$$

because $\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\rho}_{C}-\widehat{\rho}_{C}\right)=o_{\mathrm{P}}(1)$ by part (2) of Theorem 6.1, and $\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\rho}_{C}^{*}-\widehat{\rho}_{C}^{*}\right)=o_{\mathrm{P}}(1)$ by the same argument as in the proof of part (2) of Theorem 6.1 replacing Lemma 6.1 by Lemma B.4.

# Appendix C. Simulations 

We show that the asymptotic theory provides a good approximation to the behavior of the CRRR estimator through a small sample Monte Carlo simulation. In particular, we document that the CRRR estimator converges at the expected rate and that the corresponding confidence interval has coverage close to its nominal level. We focus on the correlation-based estimator, but we find very similar performance for the regression-based and fully-restricted estimators in results not reported. ${ }^{21}$

We consider a bivariate normal design for analytical convenience. In particular, we draw data from the process

$$
\binom{Y}{W} \mid X=x \sim N_{2}\left(\left(\begin{array}{l}
x \\
x
\end{array}\right),\left(\begin{array}{ll}
1 & c \\
c & 1
\end{array}\right)\right), \quad X \sim N(0,1)
$$

We consider 3 different values for the correlation parameter $c \in\{0.25,0.50,0.75\}$ and 3 sample sizes $n \in\{625,2500,10000\}$. We choose these sample sizes because they correspond to $\sqrt{n} \in$ $\{25,50,100\}$, where $\sqrt{n}$ is the theoretical rate of convergence of the CRRR estimator. The true value of the CRRR slope is obtained from $c$ using the expression of the rank correlation of the bivariate normal, $\rho_{C}=6 \arcsin (c / 2) / \pi$ (e.g., Cramér, 1999).

Table 8 shows the result from 2, 000 simulations using the correlation-based estimator of Algorithm 1 with Gaussian or probit link function, a mesh of 500 points located at sample quantiles in a sequence of orders from 0.005 to 0.995 with increments of $0.99 / 499$, and $m=30$ to estimate the tail parameters. We report root mean squared error (RMSE), bias, standard deviation (SD) and coverage of $95 \%$ confidence intervals (Cover.). The confidence intervals are obtained from Algorithm 3 by empirical bootstrap with 200 repetitions. The results indicate that (i) the estimator converges at the expected rate of $\sqrt{n}$ and (ii) the coverage of the confidence intervals floats around the nominal level of $.95 .{ }^{22}$

abstract:
Rank-rank regression is commonly employed in economic research as a way of
capturing the relationship between two economic variables. It frequently
features in studies of intergenerational mobility as the resulting coefficient,
capturing the rank correlation between the variables, is easy to interpret and
measures overall persistence. However, in many applications it is common
practice to include other covariates to account for differences in persistence
levels between groups defined by the values of these covariates. In these
instances the resulting coefficients can be difficult to interpret. We propose
the conditional rank-rank regression, which uses conditional ranks instead of
unconditional ranks, to measure average within-group persistence. The
difference between conditional and unconditional rank-rank regression
coefficients can then be interpreted as a measure of between-group persistence.
We develop a flexible estimation approach using distribution regression and
establish a theoretical framework for large sample inference. An empirical
study on intergenerational income mobility in Switzerland demonstrates the
advantages of this approach. The study reveals stronger intergenerational
persistence between fathers and sons compared to fathers and daughters, with
the within-group persistence explaining 62% of the overall income persistence
for sons and 52% for daughters. Smaller families and those with highly educated
fathers exhibit greater persistence in economic status.
